abstract.text: An object that defines specific phases of the UI update process.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: Each UI update consists of several phases that run in a consistent order, and the
object defines constants that represent these phases. When using a
, you can use these constants to decide which phase of the UI update process you want its actions to run in.
: standard and low-latency. The standard phase group runs for each UI update. This phase group includes these phases, which run in the following order:
The low-latency phase group is optional, and itâ€™s off by default. It runs only if you explicitly request low-latency event dispatch using
. The low-latency phase group includes these phases, which run in the following order (after the standard phases):
When a phase group runs, all phases inside the group run. Phases run one after another in the specified order without exiting back into the run loop.

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your iOS, iPadOS, or tvOS app.
An object that defines specific phases of the UI update process.
A phase that runs after Core Animation display link callbacks.
A phase that runs after a Core Animation transaction commit.
A phase that runs after standard event handlers.
A phase that runs after a Core Animation transaction commit for a low-latency event.
A phase that runs after low-latency event handlers.
A phase that runs at the end of a UI update.
A phase that runs after the scheduling of a UI update.
A phase that runs before Core Animation display link callbacks.
A phase that runs before a Core Animation transaction commit.
A phase that runs before standard event handlers.
A phase that runs before a Core Animation transaction commit for a low-latency event.
A phase that runs before low-latency event handlers.
An object that contains detailed information about the current UI update state.
An object you use to observe, participate in, and affect the UI update process.
A Boolean value that determines whether the UI update link requests dispatch of low-latency eligible events.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
